awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Safe and Transformative Robotic Intervention through Dynamic Elastic Structures (STRIDES)
awd_abstract_narration:
Robotic devices are currently being used in medical applications, but their prevalence is hindered by lack of capability.  This project seeks to transform the safety and effectiveness of medical interventions by advancing the capabilities of flexible robots and medical devices.  The project aims to create new mathematical models to better understand the behavior of flexible robots and to develop innovative robotic devices to increase their reach, precision, intelligence, and safety.  In collaboration with medical professionals, the project will use these results to develop robotic systems for minimally invasive surgical removal of colon cancer and upper extremity rehabilitation.  The research is fundamentally linked to an educational plan that includes middle- and high-school engineering outreach, as well as undergraduate research and open courseware development.

This research is organized along three technical thrusts that advance soft and continuum robotics knowledge in modeling, design, and sensing.  First, the project will create a novel computational framework for the dynamics of slender elastic objects that extends and unifies existing models.  The proposed approach is a unique, high-order time-discretized solution method for the hyperbolic partial-differential equations of a Cosserat rod, which has potential for increased accuracy and efficiency. Second, this project will analyze and validate two novel concepts in the design of elastic robotic structures: high-strength, variable-curvature mechanisms, and concentric agonist-antagonist elastic actuation.  These concepts are aimed at addressing the tradeoffs of range-of-motion, strength, and compactness in continuum robot design. Third, new algorithmic approaches for shape-based distributed force sensing and elastic stability assessment for elastic objects are being developed and tested. The research plan culminates in efforts to advance knowledge of robotic medical intervention at the system level for minimally-invasive robotic surgery and robot-assisted rehabilitation.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project studied new flexible robotic structures that mimic trunks, tentacles, and snakes, to advance their capabilities and their potential for use in medical applications. First, a new mathematical method was developed to create computer simulations of the dynamic movement of many kinds of flexible robot arms (i.e. soft robots driven by air or liquid pressure, robots made of elastic metal tubes or rods, and snake-like robots controlled by cables).  The method was efficient and fast enough to predict and control robot motion in real time. Second, based on these models, new algorithms were created to give flexible robots a sense of touch. By using information about the robot's shape, these methods automatically infer the forces that the robot is feeling.  This sensing capability can be used to enhance safety and perform tasks.

Finally, new flexible robotic structures were invented that addressed two major goals: strength and miniaturization. The project showed how cable lines can be redesigned to dramatically increase the load carrying capacity of flexible robot arms. Also, a very small yet strong type of flexible robot was invented using elastic metal tubes that were intelligently machined with slots to alter their mechanical properties. This new robotic structure can create steerable surgical devices with diameters smaller than a millimeter.

Intellectual Merit:

The project advanced knowledge in robotic science by creating new methods to study and understand the dynamic motion of novel flexible robots. The models and algorithms developed in the project improved upon the state of the art by increasing speed and solving previously unsolved problems, such as shape-based force sensing. The science of robot mechanism design was also advanced by uncovering the way cable line geometry affects manipulator strength and by the invention and analysis of new slotted tube mechanisms.

Broader Impacts:

The project benefitted society by enabling soft robots to safely interact with humans (through their intelligent force sensing and compliant structure) and to perform more useful tasks (through new designs with increased strength and smaller size). These benefits are especially relevant to applications in robotic surgery, where force sensing can improve safety by increasing situational awareness, and miniaturization can give surgeons remote access to hard-to-reach locations in the body. The surgical robot prototypes developed in this project have laid the groundwork for future research and commercial systems. The technology created in this project has been patented and licensed for the development of new surgical devices. The project also trained many students in robotics engineering and dynamics, by integrating the research into university courses and precollege outreach programs.


Last Modified: 01/27/2024
Modified by: Daniel C Rucker
